item.title: Ubuntu 12.04, PGSQL 9.3, PostGIS 2.1 and PL/R against libgdal1h from scratch

description.p: First we need to check which PostgreSQL, PostGIS and GDAL versions are installed. To do so check your Debian package management system (dpkg).
You should get a list like the following one:

pre.code: ii libgdal-dev 1.10.0-1~precise1 Geospatial Data Abstraction Library - Development files ii libgdal1-dev 1.10.0-1~precise1 Geospatial Data Abstraction Library - Development files ii libgdal1h 1.10.0-1~precise1 Geospatial Data Abstraction Library ii postgresql-9.1 9.1.10-0ubuntu12.04 object-relational SQL database, version 9.1 server ii postgresql-9.1-postgis-2.0 2.0.3-2~precise4 Geographic objects support for PostgreSQL 9.1 ii postgresql-9.1-postgis-2.0-scripts 2.0.3-2~precise4 Geographic objects support for PostgreSQL 9.1 -- scripts ii postgresql-client-9.1 9.1.10-0ubuntu12.04 front-end programs for PostgreSQL 9.1 ii postgresql-client-common 129ubuntu1 manager for multiple PostgreSQL client versions ii postgresql-common 129ubuntu1 PostgreSQL database-cluster manager ii postgresql-contrib-9.1 9.1.10-0ubuntu12.04 additional facilities for PostgreSQL

description.p: If you want, you could remove these packages as follow:

pre.code: apt-get purge libgdal-dev libgdal1-dev libgdal1h postgresql-9.1 postgresql-9.1-postgis-2.0 postgresql-9.1-postgis-2.0-scripts postgresql-client-9.1 postgresql-client-common postgresql-common apt-get autoremove apt-get autoclean

description.p: First you need to find out your release code name:
which get you something like that Codename: precise
Create a new file codename-pgdg.list in /etc/apt/sources.list.d according to the PostgreSQL wiki page.
and add the following line
Now we need to import the repository key from
Now we can a update the repository and install the required packages from the PostgreSQL repository.

pre.code: apt-get update apt-get install postgresql-9.3 postgresql-contrib-9.3 postgresql-server-dev-9.3

description.p: To install PostGIS 2.1 it is important that postgresql-server-dev-x.x is installed, because we need to compile PostGIS against these source files. We are going the install the precompiled libgdal 1.10.0 version from ubuntugis.
Install python-software-properties and add the apt sources (repositories):

pre.code: apt-get install python-software-properties add-apt-repository ppa:ubuntugis/ubuntugis-unstable apt-get update

description.p: Now install the new GDAL library called libgdal1h and its’ development package

pre.code: apt-get install libgdal1h apt-cache showpkg libgdal-dev*

description.p: which gets you something like that:
You can install a version using the -f flag
Before installing the PostGIS from source we install the required dependencies.

pre.code: apt-get install make gcc checkinstall libxml2-dev libproj-dev libgeos-dev

description.p: Download the latest PostGIS source and compile it

pre.code: wget http://download.osgeo.org/postgis/source/postgis-2.1.0.tar.gz tar xzvf postgis-2.1.0.tar.gz cd postgis-2.1.0 ./configure

PostGIS is now configured for x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu

description.p: use checkinstall, which runs make install and registers the package in dpkg.
Before we can install PL/R extension for PostgreSQL 9.3 we need to install R 3.0.2 as describe on the R-Project site. First edit the
and add the following line and do a update
as well as the key

pre.code: apt-key adv --keyserver keyserver.ubuntu.com --recv-keys E084DAB9 apt-get update

description.p: The search for the 3.0.2 R package version and install it.

pre.code: apt-cache showpkg r-base apt-get install -f r-base=3.0.2-1precise0

description.p: Lastly we can install the PL/R extension for PostgreSQL from the PostgreSQL apt repository
So … we are ready … have fun.

description.p: Now perform a few post-installation setup commands, in the order: (1) Initialize the database cluster (required), (2) start database (recommended, if you want to use it straight away), (3) allow it to start-up automatically on reboot (recommended):

pre.code: :::bash service postgresql-9.3 initdb service postgresql-9.3 start chkconfig postgresql-9.3 on

description.p: Some important files
In the pg_hba.conf file comment out the ident lines except for unix domain socket and add two new lines for md5 encryption

pre.code: :::yaml # IPv4 local connections: #host all all 127.0.0.1/32 ident host all all 127.0.0.1/32 md5 # IPv6 local connections: #host all all ::1/128 ident host all all ::1/128 md5
